Review Title: Bigger is not better for employees!
Job Title: Senior Director Credit, Collections and AR
Pros: Company was a better place to work pre-merger. Good place to start for people with no experience or no formal education. Stay 2 to 3 years max then move on.
Cons: Benefits are average and pay is subpar compared to industry standards. The CEO, Rich Hume, is aloof and condescending. He speaks in lofty platitudes along with the rest of the Executive Management team. Executive Management is highly reactive, not proactive. They equivocate on every topic to the point of being pathologically deceitful. The SVP of Credit & Collections, Jay Snyder, is an uncouth rustic individual that runs his division like a medieval fiefdom. He manages and controls everything including the smallest details that should be delegated to lower management. It’s very strange to see an intolerant individual like this in an organization that prides itself in diversity and inclusion. Also, top sales producers are negatively impacted by TD Synnex changing its sales commission structure making it more difficult for sales to meet goals. Eddie Franklin, SVP Sales, had nothing to say about this cut in pay! Less pay for employees and more profits for the Executive team, Board of Directors, and shareholders.

Pros: Able to learn different departments.
Cons: Management offers promotions based on favoritism.

Pros: Exposure to many different clients
Cons: Work life balance and benefits

Pros: The customers and the work you perform are great! Hundreds of different types of equipment to work on, changing all the time. Mostly PoS and small electronics repairs, plus some light I.T. work, particularly in Datacenters, Outstanding local and regional team eager to help you in any way! Lots of overnight work and travel which means more $$.
Cons: The company itself is laughably disorganized. The change their name and "reset" your employment status every few months. No one above your field manager can be contacted for any reason; and no one even knows HOW to reach them. It is a logistical nightmare, as much of your mundane tasks normally performed electronically have to be done by pen and paper, and mailed in (no exaggeration!) It takes them almost 2 years just to send you an employee badge; and by then it's no good because they'd already changed their name 3+ times! To add to the confusion, they are subcontracted by other organizations, so each WO assigned to you requires that you "pretend" that you are working for another company. This requires constant lying to their costumers, and it's basically unavoidable.

Pros: Dynamic, fun environment, great culture
Cons: Ultimately the business was not sustainable.

Pros: good company to work for

Review Title: American jobs lost and great company lost
Pros: this used to be a great company but the merger with Synnex destroyed everything that was good. I can't think of anything but pre-merger, Tech Data was a great company I spent my career at.
Cons: post merger they off shore all jobs over seas. this is no longer a company for the American people. great paying careers are now fulfilled overseas and it makes me sick to see all these jobs lost which is affecting our local Clearwater economy. the service our customers are receiving are now sub par. there's no room for growth or advancement because all job postings are over seas. no longer a company to get your foot in the door and grow. the synnex management and philosophy took over the culture and it is not welcoming. they look down and devalue all tech data employees and there is no diversity and Inclusion.

Pros: Decent pay for the work depending in role.
Cons: Higher ups are very secretive on company plans. The facility closed due to new warehouse in Ohio and our managers were told a new facility was going to be built in the same area of Chandler which was false. Techs are underpaid

Pros: Flexibility Training Management Communication Leadership

Pros:
Work from home flexibility
Large company so there are many areas you can work in or move to as your career develops
The majority of the positions can be done remotely, so you are not limited by your location
You could certainly work here at the same job for many years without being forced to move up
They offer a stable 9-5 M-F type schedule
Cons:
Executives care a lot about the sales team and very little about the back-end teams
Raises are very poor and are outpaced by inflation
Income is not a living wage
Management doesn't seem to be interested in developing their employees or helping them advance
Many teams are understaffed and overworked, leaving little opportunities for employees to use PTO without detriment, and throwing teams into chaos when someone leaves the company because there was not sufficient cross-training or backup and documentation
With the merger, the executives continually boast about company performance and how it is good for everyone, but that is not being reflected in opportunities or with annual review/raises
The company has been very unstable in recent years with all the changes at the executive level, as well as being bought and becoming a privately traded company, and then quickly becoming public again with the Synnex merger

Employees are not treated equally, some are grossly underpaid, and there is an extreme lack of diversity in leadership when it comes to women and LGBTQ+. The company used to list the salary range for every position, but stopped and now underpay some while giving more to others.

The new management is not supportive of their employees, is now almost all white men, and no matter what they preach, they no longer embrace diversity and inclusion.

Review Title: Good first job, not for long term
Pros:
My sales team was great. Everyone was very helpful and always telling new hires to ask questions all the time. Working from home 95% of the time is great too if you like the environment. 

Managers are communicative and want you to succeed. The trainings are elaborate and really do take up your first 3 months of working. Overall, a good first entry level position especially if you just graduated college
Cons:
The pay is NOT worth staying more than a year. 35k or $15 an hour is ridiculous especially with the work load. There are no incentives really for the ASR role unless you want to waste your own lunch time every day and sit in on zoom lunches and listen to the vendors speak just to make an extra $15 a day. 

The benefits are not great. I felt regrets and pressure every time i took off work because we are so "short staffed" all the time.

Pros: Big Company that knows broadband distribution very well
